title: 115_s845
content: The Act titled "Protecting Sensitive Locations Act" grants powers to immigration officers and employees at sensitive locations. Section 287 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to define terms related to enforcement actions for immigration purposes. The appropriate committees of Congress are specified, along with the definition of enforcement actions. The term 'exigent circumstances' in the context of enforcement actions for immigration purposes refers to situations involving imminent risks of death, violence, physical harm, terrorism, national security threats, immediate arrest of dangerous individuals, pursuit of felons, or destruction of evidence in criminal cases. 'Prior approval' is defined as the authorization required for officers and agents of U.S. law enforcement agencies. Prior written approval is required for officers and agents of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement to carry out enforcement actions involving specific individuals. Approval must be obtained from designated officials within the agency. Prior written approval is necessary for officers and agents of U.S. Customs and Border Protection and other law enforcement agencies to conduct enforcement actions involving specific individuals. Approval must be granted by designated officials within the respective agencies. Sensitive locations include areas within 1,000 feet of medical facilities, schools, and other educational institutions. Sensitive locations include schools, colleges, universities, educational activities, school buses, organizations assisting vulnerable individuals, and places of worship. The curr_chunk specifies various locations considered sensitive, including places of worship, courthouses, sites of ceremonies, public demonstrations, shelters, and other locations designated by the Secretary of Homeland Security. The curr_chunk outlines restrictions on enforcement actions at sensitive locations, requiring exigent circumstances and prior approval. Violations result in exclusion of information from removal proceedings. The curr_chunk discusses the ability of an alien in a removal proceeding to file a motion for immediate termination. It also outlines restrictions on enforcement actions at sensitive locations by officers of the Department of Homeland Security. The curr_chunk discusses limitations on enforcement actions at sensitive locations by officers of the Department of Homeland Security, requiring discretion and consultation with supervisors in certain situations. The curr_chunk outlines the requirement for annual training on compliance with enforcement actions at sensitive locations for employees supervised by specified officials in the Department of Homeland Security. The curr_chunk specifies the officials who must receive annual training on compliance with enforcement actions at sensitive locations within the Department of Homeland Security. This includes Field Office Directors, Special Agents in Charge, Chief Patrol Agents, Directors of Field Operations, Directors of Air and Marine Operations, Internal Affairs Special Agents in Charge, and chief law enforcement officers of State or local agencies with agreements with DHS. The Secretary of Homeland Security is also required to modify the Notice to Appear form (I-862). The Secretary of Homeland Security is mandated to modify the Notice to Appear form (I-862) to provide subjects of enforcement actions with information on restrictions at sensitive locations and available remedies. The form must be accessible to individuals with limited English proficiency and subjects cannot verify compliance with these restrictions. Additionally, the Director of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement and the Commissioner of U.S. Customs and Border Protection must each receive annual training on compliance with enforcement actions at sensitive locations. The Secretary of Homeland Security must modify the Notice to Appear form to inform individuals of restrictions at sensitive locations. The Director of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement and the Commissioner of U.S. Customs and Border Protection must undergo annual training on enforcement actions at sensitive locations. Both agencies must submit annual reports to Congress detailing enforcement actions at sensitive locations. The annual reports to Congress on enforcement actions at sensitive locations must include details such as the agency components involved, description of the enforcement action, number of individuals arrested, collateral arrests, contact with location administrator, and percentage of staff completing required training. The subsection does not affect law enforcement agencies' authority to enforce criminal laws unrelated to immigration or protect residents from public safety threats. It also does not limit the protections provided in sections 239 and 384 of the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996.
